values.description:
UPDATE: @nkoenig plans to create an alternate solution to the gui.ini issue by allowing for the specification of a gui plugin in SDF, so this pull request is at a low priority.

Instead of reading ~/.gazebo/gui.ini to read an INI configuration, GuiIface reads the environment variable GAZEBO_GUI_INI_FILE for an INI file. If the variable is not set, then it checks the default location ~/.gazebo/gui.ini.
values.title: GuiIface reads GAZEBO_GUI_INI_FILE environment variable

summary.raw:
UPDATE: @nkoenig plans to create an alternate solution to the gui.ini issue by allowing for the specification of a gui plugin in SDF, so this pull request is at a low priority.

Instead of reading ~/.gazebo/gui.ini to read an INI configuration, GuiIface reads the environment variable GAZEBO_GUI_INI_FILE for an INI file. If the variable is not set, then it checks the default location ~/.gazebo/gui.ini.
summary.html:
UPDATE: @nkoenig plans to create an alternate solution to the gui.ini issue by allowing for the specification of a gui plugin in SDF, so this pull request is at a low priority.

Instead of reading ~/.gazebo/gui.ini to read an INI configuration, GuiIface reads the environment variable GAZEBO_GUI_INI_FILE for an INI file. If the variable is not set, then it checks the default location ~/.gazebo/gui.ini.

values.description:
New function `Quaternion::Integrate` that takes angular velocity and time step as inputs.
This is motivated by [handsim pull request 4](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/pull-request/4/fix-spacenav-control-of-arm/diff).
values.title: Add helper function for integrating quaternions over constant angular velocity

summary.raw:
New function `Quaternion::Integrate` that takes angular velocity and time step as inputs.
This is motivated by [handsim pull request 4](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/pull-request/4/fix-spacenav-control-of-arm/diff).
summary.html: New function Quaternion::Integrate that takes angular velocity and time step as inputs. This is motivated by handsim pull request 4.

values.description:
This adds the polhemus model needed by HaptixControlPlugin, changes the default camera angle, and physics parameters.

To spawn the robot arm:
~~~
echo "<sdf version='1.5'><include><uri>model://model_name</uri></include></sdf>" | gz model -s -m arm2 -x 0.5 -y "-1" -z 0 -Y "-1.57"
~~~
values.title: Update arat.world for haptix usage

summary.raw:
This adds the polhemus model needed by HaptixControlPlugin, changes the default camera angle, and physics parameters.

To spawn the robot arm:
~~~
echo "<sdf version='1.5'><include><uri>model://model_name</uri></include></sdf>" | gz model -s -m arm2 -x 0.5 -y "-1" -z 0 -Y "-1.57"
~~~
summary.html:
This adds the polhemus model needed by HaptixControlPlugin, changes the default camera angle, and physics parameters.

To spawn the robot arm:

values.description:
If you build and install `examples/plugins/gui_overlay_plugin_spawn`, then you can use:

```
#!xml

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">

    <gui>
      <plugin name="sample" filename="libgui_example_spawn_widget.so"/>
    </gui>

    <!-- A global light source -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

```
values.title: Allow GUI plugins to be loaded from a world SDF file.

summary.raw:
If you build and install `examples/plugins/gui_overlay_plugin_spawn`, then you can use:

```
#!xml

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">

    <gui>
      <plugin name="sample" filename="libgui_example_spawn_widget.so"/>
    </gui>

    <!-- A global light source -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

```
summary.html:
If you build and install examples/plugins/gui_overlay_plugin_spawn, then you can use:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">

    <gui>
      <plugin name="sample" filename="libgui_example_spawn_widget.so"/>
    </gui>

    <!-- A global light source -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>
    <!-- A ground plane -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

values.description:
When in the `Model Editor`, some tools are not needed and actually confuse the user - more specifically, the insert tools (insert simple shapes and lights).

I adapted most of this from @iche033 's pull request #1079.

For now, I commented out the buttons for copy and paste, align and snap, as these tools are not working inside the editor at the moment (issues #1314, #1318, #1323).
values.title: Model Editor: Toggle visibility of actions on toolbar

summary.raw:
When in the `Model Editor`, some tools are not needed and actually confuse the user - more specifically, the insert tools (insert simple shapes and lights).

I adapted most of this from @iche033 's pull request #1079.

For now, I commented out the buttons for copy and paste, align and snap, as these tools are not working inside the editor at the moment (issues #1314, #1318, #1323).
summary.html:
When in the Model Editor, some tools are not needed and actually confuse the user - more specifically, the insert tools (insert simple shapes and lights).

I adapted most of this from @iche033 's pull request #1079.

For now, I commented out the buttons for copy and paste, align and snap, as these tools are not working inside the editor at the moment (issues #1314, #1318, #1323).

values.description:
As @hugomatic suggested on pull request #1259.

I saw there are 3 different cases:

### 1. `_parent` is always `NULL` ###

Commented it out and always add the property to `this->propTreeBrowser`

### 2. `_parent` is never `NULL` ###

`if (!_parent) return;` and always add the property to `_parent`

### 3. `_parent` might be `NULL` or not (only for links at the moment) ###

Use new `AddProperty` function
values.title: Removed unnecessary checks on Model List Widget

summary.raw:
As @hugomatic suggested on pull request #1259.

I saw there are 3 different cases:

### 1. `_parent` is always `NULL` ###

Commented it out and always add the property to `this->propTreeBrowser`

### 2. `_parent` is never `NULL` ###

`if (!_parent) return;` and always add the property to `_parent`

### 3. `_parent` might be `NULL` or not (only for links at the moment) ###

Use new `AddProperty` function
summary.html:
As @hugomatic suggested on pull request #1259.

I saw there are 3 different cases:

1. _parent is always NULL

Commented it out and always add the property to this->propTreeBrowser

2. _parent is never NULL

if (!_parent) return; and always add the property to _parent

3. _parent might be NULL or not (only for links at the moment)

Use new AddProperty function

values.description:
This pull request is mainly some refactoring to remove duplicate code (net ~380 lines removed):

* Replace repeated try/catch blocks in `ODEJoint::[GS]etParam` and `ODEUniversalJoint::[GS]etParam` with a single try/catch block that contains all the if/else if logic.
* Also replace some if blocks that check the axis index with a bit-wise AND with a `group` bitmask variable (introduced in pull request #1221 for "friction" parameter, extended to other parameters here).
* `Joint::Load`: read axis parameters in loop instead of duplicate code blocks.

Also, I threw in some test expectations for `GetParam("hi_stop")` and `GetParam("lo_stop")` to `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn`. This required some added code in `BulletJoint::GetParam`.

I also removed the private member variable `Link::scale`, since this was shadowing the protected `Entity::scale` and was un-needed.

I also noticed that the joint friction value wasn't set properly in `Joint::FillMsg`, so I updated that as well (11ec88e7ce01).

* [Jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/290/)
values.title: physics::Joint refactoring: remove lots of duplicate code

summary.raw:
This pull request is mainly some refactoring to remove duplicate code (net ~380 lines removed):

* Replace repeated try/catch blocks in `ODEJoint::[GS]etParam` and `ODEUniversalJoint::[GS]etParam` with a single try/catch block that contains all the if/else if logic.
* Also replace some if blocks that check the axis index with a bit-wise AND with a `group` bitmask variable (introduced in pull request #1221 for "friction" parameter, extended to other parameters here).
* `Joint::Load`: read axis parameters in loop instead of duplicate code blocks.

Also, I threw in some test expectations for `GetParam("hi_stop")` and `GetParam("lo_stop")` to `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn`. This required some added code in `BulletJoint::GetParam`.

I also removed the private member variable `Link::scale`, since this was shadowing the protected `Entity::scale` and was un-needed.

I also noticed that the joint friction value wasn't set properly in `Joint::FillMsg`, so I updated that as well (11ec88e7ce01).

* [Jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/290/)
summary.html:
This pull request is mainly some refactoring to remove duplicate code (net ~380 lines removed):

  • Replace repeated try/catch blocks in ODEJoint::[GS]etParam and ODEUniversalJoint::[GS]etParam with a single try/catch block that contains all the if/else if logic.
  • Also replace some if blocks that check the axis index with a bit-wise AND with a group bitmask variable (introduced in pull request #1221 for "friction" parameter, extended to other parameters here).
  • Joint::Load: read axis parameters in loop instead of duplicate code blocks.

Also, I threw in some test expectations for GetParam("hi_stop") and GetParam("lo_stop") to INTEGRATION_joint_spawn. This required some added code in BulletJoint::GetParam.

I also removed the private member variable Link::scale, since this was shadowing the protected Entity::scale and was un-needed.

I also noticed that the joint friction value wasn't set properly in Joint::FillMsg, so I updated that as well (11ec88e7ce01).

  • Jenkins build

values.description:
This fixes the issue with mouse events described on issue #1326. 

It wasn't possible to insert new models into the scene after the model editor had been closed because the `JointMaker`'s filters were still there catching mouse events. `ModelCreator`'s filters were also not being removed.
values.title: Model Editor: Fix adding/removing event filters

summary.raw:
This fixes the issue with mouse events described on issue #1326. 

It wasn't possible to insert new models into the scene after the model editor had been closed because the `JointMaker`'s filters were still there catching mouse events. `ModelCreator`'s filters were also not being removed.
summary.html:
This fixes the issue with mouse events described on issue #1326.

It wasn't possible to insert new models into the scene after the model editor had been closed because the JointMaker's filters were still there catching mouse events. ModelCreator's filters were also not being removed.

values.description:
A plugin that can be configured in the world file to:emit events when:
* the simulation is paused/resumed
* a model enters/leaves a region in space
* a model is created/destroyed

the events are published with SimEvent proto on the "/gazebo/sim_events" topic.

This is a subset of the Mentor2 scoring utilities. More events (going through a gate, falling) will be added in the future.

The test/integration/sim_events.cc uses the test/world/sim_events.world where the SimEvents are specified.
values.title: SimEvents

values.description:
Suppress mouse events to avoid manipulating models not being edited.

This will be specially useful when using tools like snap and align inside the editor, since these will be used among model parts only.

values.description:
this is done through a few steps:

  * at the end of quickstep.cc, aggregate external forces and constraint forces into `facc` and `tacc`
  * cache force `facc` and torque `tacc` into local variables in Link::MoveCallback()
  * fix Link::GetWorldForce() and Link::GetWorldTorque() by polling cached Link::force and Link::torque

also:

  * added an ImuSensorPlugin and corresponding test world
  * update unit test `imu.cc`
values.title: issue #243 fix Link::GetWorldLinearAccel and Link::GetWorldAngularAccel for ODE

summary.raw:
this is done through a few steps:

  * at the end of quickstep.cc, aggregate external forces and constraint forces into `facc` and `tacc`
  * cache force `facc` and torque `tacc` into local variables in Link::MoveCallback()
  * fix Link::GetWorldForce() and Link::GetWorldTorque() by polling cached Link::force and Link::torque

also:

  * added an ImuSensorPlugin and corresponding test world
  * update unit test `imu.cc`
summary.html:
this is done through a few steps:

  • at the end of quickstep.cc, aggregate external forces and constraint forces into facc and tacc
  • cache force facc and torque tacc into local variables in Link::MoveCallback()
  • fix Link::GetWorldForce() and Link::GetWorldTorque() by polling cached Link::force and Link::torque

also:

  • added an ImuSensorPlugin and corresponding test world
  • update unit test imu.cc

values.description:
This class takes in a google protobuf message and generates widgets for configuring its properties.

This is going to be used by the model editor

* For some message types: geometry, pose, vector3, color - a custom widget is created as opposed to generating a widget for each individual field mainly for aesthetics

* TODOs: parsing and generating widgets for repeated fields, and enum fields.
values.title: Add new ConfigWidget class

summary.raw:

* TODOs: parsing and generating widgets for repeated fields, and enum fields.

values.description:
This is the first of a few changes to the Building Editor's popups.

## Changes: ##

* When there's nothing drawn, leave the editor without any popups

* Changed text on `Exit` popup and buttons

* Changed text on `Discard`'s buttons

* Change button text from `Save As` to `Save` only if the user has really saved

* Properly add the model to the scene on `Exit->Save` (before the temp model would remain)

The new flow should be working like this:

![popups4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/173121172-popups4.png)
values.title: Buildind Editor: Some changes to popups

summary.raw:
This is the first of a few changes to the Building Editor's popups.

## Changes: ##

* When there's nothing drawn, leave the editor without any popups

* Changed text on `Exit` popup and buttons

* Changed text on `Discard`'s buttons

* Change button text from `Save As` to `Save` only if the user has really saved

* Properly add the model to the scene on `Exit->Save` (before the temp model would remain)

The new flow should be working like this:

![popups4.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/173121172-popups4.png)
summary.html:

Changes:

  • When there's nothing drawn, leave the editor without any popups

  • Changed text on Exit popup and buttons

  • Changed text on Discard's buttons

  • Change button text from Save As to Save only if the user has really saved

  • Properly add the model to the scene on Exit->Save (before the temp model would remain)

The new flow should be working like this:

values.description:
This pull request enables the C++11 support. There is an issue with GTEST when using `EXPECT_TRUE` or `ASSERT_TRUE` and we pass a shared pointer as an argument. The boost::shared_ptr bool operator is explicit and the compiler does not make an implicit conversion for us when we're using these GTEST macros. 

I would say that the cleanest solution would be to use the bool operator in the form of a `static_cast<bool>(mysharedPtr)` or `bool(mysharedPtr)`. However we have lots of lines where we are comparing the shared pointer with NULL. So, for consistency this is the way I chose here to fix the problem.

There are other ways as redeclare `ASSERT_TRUE` with a different name and wrap it with a new ASSERT_TRUE but not sure if it's worth it.

Answering @_jrivero_ here: This will force the users in Ubuntu Precise to download a modern version of gcc in order to compile Gazebo. We were discussing this issue a few days ago in person but we can follow up here.
values.title: C++11 support

summary.raw:
This pull request enables the C++11 support. There is an issue with GTEST when using `EXPECT_TRUE` or `ASSERT_TRUE` and we pass a shared pointer as an argument. The boost::shared_ptr bool operator is explicit and the compiler does not make an implicit conversion for us when we're using these GTEST macros. 

I would say that the cleanest solution would be to use the bool operator in the form of a `static_cast<bool>(mysharedPtr)` or `bool(mysharedPtr)`. However we have lots of lines where we are comparing the shared pointer with NULL. So, for consistency this is the way I chose here to fix the problem.

There are other ways as redeclare `ASSERT_TRUE` with a different name and wrap it with a new ASSERT_TRUE but not sure if it's worth it.

Answering @_jrivero_ here: This will force the users in Ubuntu Precise to download a modern version of gcc in order to compile Gazebo. We were discussing this issue a few days ago in person but we can follow up here.
summary.html:
This pull request enables the C++11 support. There is an issue with GTEST when using EXPECT_TRUE or ASSERT_TRUE and we pass a shared pointer as an argument. The boost::shared_ptr bool operator is explicit and the compiler does not make an implicit conversion for us when we're using these GTEST macros.

I would say that the cleanest solution would be to use the bool operator in the form of a static_cast<bool>(mysharedPtr) or bool(mysharedPtr). However we have lots of lines where we are comparing the shared pointer with NULL. So, for consistency this is the way I chose here to fix the problem.

There are other ways as redeclare ASSERT_TRUE with a different name and wrap it with a new ASSERT_TRUE but not sure if it's worth it.

Answering @jrivero here: This will force the users in Ubuntu Precise to download a modern version of gcc in order to compile Gazebo. We were discussing this issue a few days ago in person but we can follow up here.

values.reason: We need to do more research before committing to C++11 to make sure that we won't have problems in the future.

values.description:
Issue #391

I thought of making a pull request for each item, but the code is very similar so I don't think it will be too complicated to review it all at once. In any case, each of the 3 commits should have all the changes relative to the respective item:

* 19d2d50: Wall segment color on wall segment inspector

* 0d0eee5: Stairs color on stairs inspector

* 728900a: Floor color on level inspector

Example preview and saved model:
![colors3.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4117822154-colors3.png)

Next pull request will make lower levels opaque, and higher levels wire outlines.

values.description:
`RotateYaw()` was deprecated in pull request #1235 but we still have one test using it.

@jacquelinekay, @nkoenig: there was no previous entry in migration.md, I just added what I think would be correct, give it a look. I'm also not sure if it worths to mention these changes in the changelog.md.
values.title: Migrate camera test using deprecated function

values.description:
I believe I introduced a bug on pull request #1283, clicking the `Done` button crashes Gazebo.

It's happening because `g_editModelAct` keeps on being triggered indefinitely.

This seems to fix it, but since there's still issue #1326 to be solved, I left some lines commented, because this will certainly be revisited.
values.title: Model Editor: Fix leaving model editor on Done
